content.description:
Starts near the rock shaped like a ladder. Use the flake feature to get to the bolt line. You will negotiate a crimpy section for a few bolts. After the fourth bolt, traverse right before you have to come back left. 
 You will then end up in the shared section of the route to the right (Simonize 5.12b). 
 If you make it up there, keep it together because the rest is only 12b.

First of the last five routes that all start on the lower level.
10 bolts + anchor

Climb behind the tree by scrambling up the ladder type feature. Clip the first bolt and get up the ledge of "Le château d'If". The line follows the crack all the way to the top. First route to the right of the pure trad line "Le château d'If" 6 bolts + anchor
Need a few pros in between the bolts.

climbs.name: Comte de Montecristo
climbs.fa: Socrate Badeau, Simon Brunette, Guy Parent 2008-10

content.description:
Stick clip the first bolt because there is a lack of feet until you reach the undercling. 
 There is a small bouldery section to get to a 5.10 section in the middle of the route. 
 Once you exit the final rest, the route goes along a left leaning crack/dihedral with good holds for the most part. There is only one thin section but if you read it well and don't waist any time, the onsight is within reach.

Between the two 5.13's. It shares the start of the 5.12b Simonize.
12 bolts + anchor

climbs.name: Fakir
climbs.fa: FA Eric Leclerc (sept 2020) , equipped by Guy Parent

content.description:
A big thank you to Guy Parent for opening his project so someone else could do a first ascent. This is a very generous gesture.

Guy found a really nice line in Fakir. The first bolt is quite high so a stick clip is advised. There are three cruxy sections. The first one not long after starting the route is a powerful one. The second one comes after an easy section where you can rest and is more techy. The third one is more of a pumpy one. You'll need to read the end properly if you want to keep it at the grade.

One of the best lines at Tranchant but the top might be wet very often in the Spring and after rain.



10 bolts + anchor.

10 plaquettes plus le relais.

The first 15 feet has good holds with a few long moves including a nice vertical crack. Take a sit down rest before you takle the real thing. Tall people can clip the fixed draw standing on the ledge others will go left a bit to clip and come back right to attack the crux. No beta spoiler!!! Once you figure out the crux, an easy section will bring you to a nice 5.11b face climb. After the sixth draw, move slightly right and clip the last draw of Pleurotte. You will then end up at the Pleurotte anchor. This is just left of Pleurotte.
You have to walk up to a two level ledge to start this one. 7 bolts + anchor

If you don't trad climb and want to climb this one, just climb "Mercedes 5.11a" then go clip the anchor of "L'Évasion". You can lower to the anchor of "Le château d'If" and top rope it or pull the rope down and lead it. There is a hard boulder sequence for the grade. It starts at the anchor of "Le château d'If 5.10b" trad route. 6 bolts + anchor
This is a second pitch. The first one is all trad.

Look for the obvious roof on top, head up the face to a left going ramp to the roof, clear it from the left (crux getting on top of it) and keep fighting to the belay. Trouvez le petit toit évident au haut de la paroi, montez la face jusquà une rampe se dirigeant vers la gauche du toit. Surmontez le toit (crux) et continuez de vous débattre jusquà l'encrage. Stick clip start.
12 bolts

Start on the right end of an angled ledge, underneath a right facing corner and roof. Follow the corner up to the roof. Clear the roof using the hand crack, lever and balance yourself in the corner (crux) before traversing right to the bolted anchor. Commencez à la droite de la vire, en dessous d'un coin faisant face à  droite suivi d'un toit. Suivre la fissure dans le coin jusqu'au toit, passez le toit et rétablissez vous dans le coin (crux) avant de rejoindre le relais à droite. Double hands-fist

Doublez taille main-poing

climbs.name: Malédiction du Tranchant
climbs.fa: Patrick Poirier, Simon Brunette, Sophie Lavallee 06/09/2009

content.description:
Start on the left side of the ledge. Climb the arete and then finish on the face. The anchor is a bit to the left.

Scramble up to a ledge
11 bolts

The best 5.11a face climb that I know of in Quebec. It's possible to skip the trad start by climbing the dihedral/chimney a few feet right of the start. It's still safer to use a couple of cams but the climbing is really easy. I highly recommend the real version. It adds to the pump. Once you reach the first bolt, the face climbing starts and you will fight the pump even if all of the holds are good. It is long, non-stop and no chalk visible because the rain cleans it. There are a lot of moves so it's hard to remember a sequence if you want to give it burns. The fourth route on the ledge. 10 bolts + anchor
Need 3 or 4 small pros until you reach the first bolt. The rest is all sport.

Pitch 1 5.8 13B 30m 
 1st pitch is best, only do second pitch if you want to top out. You can rap from 1st pitch (anchors available)Fairly sustained 5.8 climbing. Not pumpy but you will have to smear a bit and expect a funky offset slab 2/3 of the way up first pitch. Great little layback to get off this slab. 
  
 V1 5.8 13B 30m 
 Same start but take the second ramp and follow to the same anchor. 
  
 Pitch 2 5.8 7B 19m 
 From the belay, traverse left to join a large corner. Continue up to a large ledge. climb the last bump.

You need to climb on a small dirt and rock step slab to access the base of the route.
Bolts all the way up...spacing is good, no runnouts on first pitch. Belay / rappel anchors at top of first pitch. Stickclip for first bolt recommended but not absolutely necessary.

There is no hard crux in this route. Besides the runout at the top which is really easy for the grade, this is an excellent route for your first 5.10c. All the holds are good but for a few of them, you will have to find the proper position. Highly recommended!!! Third route from the left on the ledge. 10 bolts + anchor
Just before the anchor, there is a runout where you could use a small cam but this section is only 5.8.

The first bolt is quite high and require a bit of scrambling before you can stick-clip it. 
 There is really just a short section that makes this route 5.11c. 
 Climb under the roof on the left. Once you pull the roof, you get to easier ground.

This is the second to last route of the whole crag at the extreme right.
7 bolts + anchor

Head up the face on the bolted line to the left of Tonerre de Brest. Head to a small right facing ramp to a tiny roof. Follow the left angling crack (crux) to the top. 
  
 Suivez la ligne de plaquettes a gauche de Tonerre de Brest. 
 Continuez en petit coin ouvert vers la droite jusqu'à un petit dévers. 
 Suivez la fissure diagonale vers la gauche (crux) jusqu'au rétablissement sur la vire et l'ancrage.

Stick clip, 13 Bolts

Unfortunately, this route stays wet late in the spring, especially if there was heavy snow over the winter. 
 Even if the start is fairly easy, you should stick-clip the first bolt since the rock is flaky and fragile. 
 You will encounter the first easy (but hard to figure out) crux between the 2nd and 3rd bolt. You can either go straight up or veer slightly to the right. 
 A few easy moves lead you to the 4th bolt. You will then run in to a 5.12b/c bouldery crux. Once you pull this crux, traverse left on a small ledge and take a nice long rest. A couple more easy moves will bring you to an almost no-hands rest. Clip the 8th bolt and continue right away on to the 9th bolt to clip but climb back down to get one last shake. 
 Think twice before you attack the last section which is only one bolt + anchor but it consists of 20 hand and 20 feet movements on really small features. They are all biting but really small. If you don't make it to the anchor, you can expect a long fall. 
 It's easier if you use a jug high and left of the anchor to make the final clip. 
 The last third of this route is like a well-planned dance routine.

Second route from extremity of the cliff.
9 bolts + quick clip anchor

Stick clip because there is a lack of good feet at the start until you reach the undercling. A stiffer section leads you to easier ground and a good rest. At the fifth bolt, instead of going up in Comte de Montecristo, put a long draw/sling and traverse in Boson de la Merci. The traverse is a bit exposed. 
 This way, you skip the cruxes of both routes on either side making it for a pumpy 12b.

Shares the same start as for Comte de Montecristo.
12 bolts + anchor

Vertical climb with some slightly overhanging sections, three cruxy sections with good rests in between. Happy climbing! Voie verticale légèrement déversante par endroit avec trois sections cruxy et de bons repos entre ces sections. Bonne grimpe ! Far right.

La dernière voie a droite 14 bolts, watch the drag

A row of closely spaced bolts heading to a small dihedral topping out on a ramp heading up on the left, follow the ramp to the anchor. Stick clip!
15 bolts... seriously possible to skip a few of them, keep draws/slings for the belay

Super technical and delicate climbing, bring your crimping skills and everything will go fine. Not the easiest 12a to onsight.

There are four routes starting on that ledge. This one is the second one from the left.
11 bolts + anchor

Follow the obvious flake up until you have to step onto the face (crux) and veer slightly right to the anchor. Outstanding line!

bolts to anchor

Head up the ramp, overcome the roof while taking care of the fragile flakes, reach the dihedral and follow it to the belay. 
  
 Suivez la rampe faisant face a gauche jusqu'au petit toit, faites attentions aux prises délicates, atteignez le dièdre et suivez le jusqu'en haut.

at the far left of the rock ledge

11 bolts

Left Area 
 Middle Area 
 Right Area 
  
 Welcome to some of the harder routes at the cliff. Many routes start from the top of a ledge where a fall could be pretty nasty, many routes are setup that stick clipping the first bolt is essential, a couple cams in the ledge could also be helpful to protect the belayer. 
 Most of the routes in this sector are often wet in the spring. 
  
 Bienvenu aux voies les plus difficiles de Tranchant. Plusieurs des voies partent du haut d'une vire d’où une chute serait assez néfaste, plusieurs des voies ont été équipé pour nécessiter un stick clip, une couple de cams dans la vire peuvent aussi être de mise pour l'assureur. 
 Plusieurs des voies ici peuvent rester mouillées longtemps au printemps.
